Regarding sending useful cargo in year missions:

I speculate that the reasoning isn't really about economics. Certainly it makes sense that you wouldn't send crew and billion dollar satellites on a 60/40 mission, but what about, say, crates of bottled water for the ISS? I don't know the cost breakdown, but it's seems that the added cost of a speculative berthing operation must be relatively small compared to a launch, and therefore a good gamble.

I'm guessing it's really about reputation. Whenever a test mission has partial success, there's a perceived ding in reputation. "Sorry, we lost your water shipment" is a message that has its own costs, compared to "dang, Elon's car blew up". To combat this effect, the bean counters make a clear distinction between actual missions and test missions. Any added value, even if it's a clear net benefit, blurs this distinction. Therefore wasting these opportunities seems to be the better option.

Also, this thinking is perhaps a cultural legacy of the cost-plus economy which discouraged cost reducing ideas.

I'd hope that we can change the thinking on the matter. The BFR test launch could deliver a hell of a lot of speculative commodity payload.

Naturally Roskosmos had nothing good to say about this. SpaceX has already been eating their lunch, taking the bulk of commercial launches, and soon there will be very little market in which they can compete. Even manned flight, once SpaceX and Boeing have their capsules flying, nobody is going to want to ride on Soyuz. And, of course, the Falcon rockets and the new capsules are not merely going to seize the existing space market, they are going to greatly expand that market. Unmanned payloads, and people of all kinds, that never could have seen orbit before will begin to do so now, and Roskosmos will have none of that market. In a couple of years, the only thing Roskosmos is going to be doing is hauling Russian government flights, while the rest of the world beats a path to America's door.
And looking still farther, but not that far, down the line, BFR. That will completely revolutionize space travel (as if the Falcons aren't already doing so) and Russia will have no answer, and not even be able to participate in any way.
I am reminded of a cartoon I saw in Omni magazine about the time of the first Space Shuttle flight. In a hangar, is a large, Space Shuttle like object with a great big steam shovel attachment coming out of the payload bay. Some poor guy is being put up against the wall in front of a firing squad, while the commisar is saying, "No, No Ivan! Orders were building Space *Shuttle*, not shovel!"
The Russians have continued to have a respectable space program all through the Shuttle era, and outlasted it. Soon, they will be like wooden boats in the age of iron steam ships, and they know it.

The fairings are slick on the inside and have a higher mass on craft connector ends than on the tip of the cone end. They need to add ridges and valleys to the inside walls of the fairings in a specific pattern to "balance" and control deflection of the air.   The balance needs to be achieved with the chute deployed not in it's packed and secured state. About the flat earthers: you could call them flat brainers, as Dan from the Nerdist channel did. I can understand why they think that way, though: it's a mental condition very akin to desire for vengeance (yeah, vengeance is a mental condition too, if one most of us pass through several times in their lives) . They hate and despise the ruling class (and there are many very good reasons for this). So, as any vengeful person, they need to vent the pain-like internal pressure produced by the emotions they don't want to face in some kind of activity. They certainly refuse to see anything positive their enemy could do, so when some one present any kind of pseudo proof of their supposed lies, its like godsend to them.
Not that the ruling class don't lie or don't ever do any kind of conspiracy, of course, as history shows us (remember the imaginary weapons of mass destruction of Sadam Hussein? Or Peace Nobel Price to Obama, after he helped destroy Libya?). But to them, every doubt looks like a major conspiracy.

Great live stream Tim. (too bad I was at work when you aired it. ) I think the Falcon Heavy center core would have been quite a bit heavier than a standard Falcon 9, The reinforcement it needed for the side boosters, the extra pneumatics etc would have certainly added weight and therefore (probably) needed all three engines to slow it down. This is only speculation on my part and not fact, but it seems the most probable theory to me.
Scotty.

Geostationary orbit CIRCUMFERENCE is 265,000km (about 165,000 miles), so as you say if satellites were spread out in that orbit they'd be a long way apart. Satellites are bunched up a bit, because land masses are. There will be less over the Pacific than over Europe or the USA. Many satellite locations actually consist of several satellites a few miles apart which to all intents and purposes are at the same location in the sky. For example, Astra at 19.2 degrees East has multiple satellites, Astra-A, Astra-B...

To further clarify, Govsat-1 may well have landed had a drone ship been there. It soft landed in the ocean without exploding and floated for a few days. FH centre core failed to ignite 3 engines. It got one going which wasn't enough. Had they attempted a standard profile anding, they might have succeeded, although it's likely there wasn't enough fuel on board for that. The failure was due to lack of engine starter, not lack of fuel. TBH, it's lucky it missed the drone ship. I doubt the ship would have survived the impact.

You need to brush up on your Latin. "Binaural" means "relating to two ears" i.e. stereo sound. It's pronounced "BY-NAWRAL".

In the early days of the space programme, sand was often used as "ballast" on rocket test flights. I know that Redstone/Jupiter Cs and the early Saturn Is were flown with dummy upper stages filled with ballast. It is pretty much standard practice for rocket test flights.

Also a big thumbsup from me for TMRO. I've been watching their Saturday broadcasts and other stuff for over a year now.

Hi Tim, The single stage to orbit BFS requires surprisingly little delta-V to deorbit, see Youtube video on can you throw things out of orbit. So it's more than likely that BFS is designed to have enough fuel to do this. Bear in mind that the ship's fuel is almost depleted by now. If it was being used to supply a LOT of stuff to the ISS then its mass will be further reduced. Finally, the landing burn is likely to be of the the high burn low time, rather than medium medium medium time type that have been landed so far. This will require smallest amount of fuel possible. Note that Govsat-1 and FH both attempted this type of landing. So the last two landing failures are NOT standard landing profiles. When perfected, this will advance SpaceX further down the line of reusability with minimum performance sacrifice. From a personal level, if flying Falcon, I'd prefer the medium burn medium time. It's shown to be a lot more reliable and the G-forces are more tolerable (by grand parents - for starters).

I did a quick back of envelope calculation for satellites. If you had 10,000 satellites evenly spaced out in the volume between 200km and 1000km each satellite would have just under 49 million cubic kilometres of space to itself.

Why not just parachute them into the sea with flotation devices and a locator beacon, then pootle on over to them and fish them out.
